awd_titl_txt: Action influences on visual processing near the hands
awd_abstract_narration:
Vision routinely provides information about how to reach for and grasp objects in the environment. Can action similarly inform our visual experience of the world?  The goal of this research is to determine whether the ability to reach out and grasp an object enhances visual information that helps people interact more effectively with their immediate surroundings. The research will also assess whether training to grasp objects in novel ways can influence people's visual experience. An enhanced understanding of how the action of grasping might alter visual perception can inform the design of applications for handheld mobile devices such as smartphones and tablets and can help tailor interfaces to enhance user experience and safety. In addition, the project provides opportunities for high school students and Native American college students to become involved in STEM research (through the North Dakota Governor's School program and the NSF-funded NATURE program).

How does the capacity for action shape visual cognition? Observers process objects that are within peripersonal space  (objects they can easily grasp with their hands) differently than objects outside of their reach. A series of psychophysical experiments evaluates the hypothesis that changes in visual processing of graspable objects near the hands reflect an adaptation of the visual system to behavioral contexts. Dr. Thomas will examine how grasp posture creates affordances for action that bias processing of action-relevant visual information. Visual biases associated with power grip and precision grip postures will also be evaluated in situations with differing visual processing task demands. Potential plasticity of alterations in visual processing near the hands will be evaluated by determining whether action-specific training alters how observers process action-relevant visual information. These experiments explore the potential influence of both bottom-up and top-down mechanisms that may contribute to altered vision near the hands and determine the relationships between visual biases associated with the planning of dynamic actions and those associated with static hand postures.  More generally, the work evaluates the malleability of the relationship between body position and visual perception, attention, and memory.

por.por_cntn:
We use visual information to accurately reach for and grasp objects in the environment, but interestingly, our ability to interact with nearby objects can also inform our visual experience of the world. This project found that when observers are positioned at the ready to perform an action such as grasping a hammer, holding a pencil, or taking a step, the brain prioritizes incoming visual information that will aid in performing that action. These action-relevant visual processing biases were malleable, changing as a result of recent experience; when participants in the lab spent a few minutes learning how to grasp objects by using the backs of their hands, for example, they subsequently showed increased visual sensitivity to information they saw near the backs of their hands. An experiment in the laboratory examining action-relevant visual biases for images of real objects suggests that these biases may not occur when an observer views an object they cannot pick up and grasp. Additional work found that the brain may also prioritize visual information near handheld, but not remotely operated, tools. Taken together, our findings suggest that body-based circumstances inform visual processing, reflecting the sensitivity of perception and visual cognition to behavioral contexts.

 

This project integrated education and research by creating training opportunities for a postdoctoral scholar and graduate student as well as dozens of undergraduate research assistants. Lab personnel at all levels participated in the design of experiments, collection and analysis of data, and presentation of results to the scientific community. Members of the research team also participated in a summer camp program (the Nurturing American Tribal Undergraduate Research and Education or NATURE program) that provided Native American students the opportunity to visit the laboratory and learn about research activities. The findings from this project can potentially inform applied studies about best practices when viewing information on handheld devices such as smartphones and tablets.
